title: Altria Stock, Philip Morris Are Rising as Cigarette Merger Is Abandoned
text:
Text size

Altria Group and Philip Morris International aren’t merging after all, while Juul Labs—partly owned by Altria —is changing CEOs and its approach to marketing in the U.S.

Both big tobacco companies said Wednesday they will remain separate entities. Shareholders of both firms seemed unenthusiastic about the potential deal when talks were announced last month, and stock in both tobacco giants was up in premarket trading Wednesday.

“While we believed the creation of a new merged company had the potential to create incremental revenue and cost synergies, we could not reach agreement,” said Altria CEO Howard Willard.

Philip Morris International stock (ticker: PM) was up 7.2% to $76.71, while Altria stock (MO) rose 3.4% to $42.10.

The news coincides with a shake-up at Juul Labs, which is 35% owned by Altria. CEO Kevin Burns is stepping down. He will be succeeded by K.C. Crosthwaite, who is leaving his role as chief strategy and growth officer at Altria.

Regulatory pushback has been mounting against Juul Labs. The San Francisco company is seen as Altria’s hedge against a cigarette-free future. But investigations and vaping-related bans at the state and local levels could have complicated merger talks.

Juul said Wednesday it will suspend all broadcast, print and digital product advertising in the U.S., adding it will also refrain from lobbying the Food and Drug Administration. The company has faced concern that its marketing tactics appealed to teenagers

In a statement, Crosthwaite cited the “unacceptable levels of youth usage and eroding public confidence” facing the vaping industry. “Against that backdrop, we must strive to work with regulators, policy makers and other stakeholders, and earn the trust of the societies in which we operate,” he said.

Philip Morris CEO André Calantzopoulos said in a statement that it and Altria will focus on launching the IQOS device—a heat-not-burn tobacco product—in the U.S. “as part of their mutual interest to achieve a smoke-free future.”

IQOS has received pre-sale approval from the FDA, though Philip Morris has also applied for less strict regulations. Philip Morris sells IQOS overseas, while Altria will sell it in the U.S.
